csvData.title: LONG-TERM MONTHLY AVERAGES OF SOLAR RADIATION AND METEOROLOGICAL PARAMETERS
csvData.GHIm: GHIm - Average monthly sum of global horizontal irradiation (© {year} Solargis) [kWh/m2]
csvData.Diffm: Diffm - Average daily sum of diffuse horizontal irradiation (© {year} Solargis) [kWh/m2]
csvData.DNIm: DNIm - Average monthly sum of direct normal irradiation (© {year} Solargis) [kWh/m2]
csvData.T24: T24 - Average diurnal (24-hour) air temperature at 2 m above ground. Calculated from outputs of ERA-5 model (© 2019 ECMWF) [deg. C]
csvData.ALBm: ALBm - Fraction of solar irradiance reflected by surface. Ratio of upwelling to downwelling (GHI) radiative fluxes at the surface. (Derived from NASA MODIS and ECMWF ERA-5) []
csvData.WSm: WSm - Average monthly wind speed at 10 m above ground. Calculated from outputs of MERRA-2 and CFSv2 models (© {year} NOAA and NASA) [m/s]
csvData.RHm: RHm - Average monthly relative humidity at 2 m above ground. Calculated from outputs of MERRA-2 and CFSv2 models (© {year} NASA and NOAA) [%]
csvData.PWATm: PWATm - Precipitable water is the depth of water vapour in a column of the atmosphere, if all the water in that column were precipitated as rain. It indicates the amount of moisture above ground. Calculated from outputs of CFSR and CFSv2 models (© {year} NOAA) [kg/m2]
csvData.PRECm: PRECm - Average monthly sums of precipitation derived from Global Precipitation Climatology database (© {year} DWD) [mm]
csvData.SNOWDm: SNOWDm - Snow days are calculated as days with snow water depth equivalent to or higher than 5 mm. Calculated from outputs of CFSR and CFSv2 models (© 2019 NOAA) [days]
csvData.CDDm: CDDm - Quantifies energy demand needed to cool a building. "Cooling degree days" are a measure of how much (in degrees), and for how long (in days), outside air temperature was higher than a specific base daily average temperature (18°C). Yearly and monthly values are aggregated from daily values. Calculated by Solargis from air temperature data [degree days]
csvData.HDDm: HDDm - Quantifies energy demand needed to heat a building. "Heating degree days" are a measure of how much (in degrees), and for how long (in days), outside air temperature was lower than a specific base daily average temperature (18°C). Yearly and monthly values are aggregated from daily values. Calculated by Solargis from air temperature data [degree days]

ALB.desc: Fraction of solar irradiance reflected by surface. Ratio of upwelling to downwelling (GHI) radiative fluxes at the surface
ALB.name: Surface albedo

AZI.desc: Terrain aspect towards the cardinal directions in degrees, clockwise. North=0, East=90, South=180, West=270. Flat terrain (SLO < 2 degrees) is not considered
AZI.name: Terrain azimuth

CDD.desc: Quantifies energy demand needed to cool a building. "Cooling degree days" are a measure of how much (in degrees), and for how long (in days), outside air temperature was higher than a specific base daily average temperature (18°C). Yearly and monthly values are aggregated from daily values
CDD.name: Cooling degree days

CF.desc: The ratio of an actual electrical energy output over a year to the maximum possible electrical energy output over a year expressed in %. The maximum possible power production is the AC installed capacity times the number of hours in a year, while the actual production is the amount of electricity delivered annually from the project.
CF.name: Capacity factor

D2G.desc: Ratio of diffuse horizontal irradiation and global horizontal irradiation (DIF/GHI)
D2G.name: Ratio of diffuse to global irradiation

DIF.desc: Average yearly, monthly or daily sum of diffuse horizontal irradiation
DIF.name: Diffuse horizontal irradiation

DNI.desc: Average yearly, monthly or daily sum of direct normal irradiation
DNI.name: Direct normal irradiation

DNI_season.desc: Ratio of maximum and minimum monthly averages of direct normal irradiation (DNI_month_max/DNI_month_min)
DNI_season.name: DNI seasonality

ELE.desc: Elevation of terrain surface above/below sea level
ELE.name: Terrain elevation

GHI.desc: Average annual, monthly or daily sum of global horizontal irradiation
GHI.name: Global horizontal irradiation

GHI_season.desc: Ratio of maximum and minimum monthly averages of global horizontal irradiation (GHI_month_max/GHI_month_min)
GHI_season.name: GHI seasonality

GTI.desc: Average annual, monthly or daily sum of global tilted irradiation
GTI.name: Global tilted irradiation

GTI_opta.desc: Average annual, monthly or daily sum of global tilted irradiation for PV modules fix-mounted at optimum angle
GTI_opta.name: Global tilted irradiation at optimum angle

GTI_theoretical.desc: Average annual, monthly or daily sum of global tilted irradiation without consideration of terrain shading
GTI_theoretical.name: Global tilted irradiation (theoretical)

HDD.desc: Quantifies energy demand needed to heat a building. "Heating degree days" are a measure of how much (in degrees), and for how long (in days), outside air temperature was lower than a specific base daily average temperature (18°C). Yearly and monthly values are aggregated from daily values
HDD.name: Heating degree days

LANDC.desc: Indicates the prevailing type of material at the surface (grass, forest, urbanized area, etc.)
LANDC.name: Land cover

OPTA.desc: Optimum tilt of fix-mounted PV modules facing towards Equator set for maximizing GTI input
OPTA.name: Optimum tilt of PV modules

POPUL.desc: Average number of infabitants per unit area
POPUL.name: Population density

PR.desc: Ratio between specific AC electricity output of a PV system and global tilted irradiation received by the surface of a PV array (PVOUTspecific/GTI)
PR.name: Performance ratio

PREC.desc: Average yearly and monthly sums of precipitation
PREC.name: Precipitation (rainfall)

PVGAIN_cdte.desc: Ratio between annual yield of PV systems based on CdTe and cSi modules (PVOUTcdte/PVOUTcsi)
PVGAIN_cdte.name: Gain of CdTe over CSi modules

PVOUT_cdte.desc: Yearly yield from a PV system using CdTe modules. Calculated using solar radiation and air temperature data
PVOUT_cdte.name: PV CdTe yield

PVOUT_csi.desc: Yearly yield from a PV system using cSi modules. Calculated using solar radiation and air temperature data
PVOUT_csi.name: PV cSi yield

PVOUT_specific.desc: Yearly and monthly average values of photovoltaic electricity (AC) delivered by a PV system and normalized to 1 kWp of installed capacity
PVOUT_specific.name: Specific photovoltaic power output

PVOUT_total.desc: Yearly and monthly average values of photovoltaic electricity (AC) delivered by the total installed capacity of a PV system
PVOUT_total.name: Total photovoltaic power output

PWAT.desc: Precipitable water is the depth of water vapour in a column of the atmosphere, if all the water in that column were precipitated as rain. It indicates the amount of moisture above ground
PWAT.name: Precipitable water

RH.desc: Average yearly or monthly relative humidity at 2 m above ground
RH.name: Relative humidity

SNOWD.desc: Snow days are calculated as days with snow water depth equivalent to or higher than 5 mm
SNOWD.name: Snow days

TEMP.desc: Average yearly, monthly and daily air temperature at 2 m above ground
TEMP.name: Air temperature

WS.desc: Average yearly, monthly and daily wind speed at 10 m above ground
WS.name: Wind speed

transfer.title: Transfer {projects, plural, one {project} other {# projects}}
transfer.info:
By transferring a project, you will transfer project information (project name, location, etc.) and PV configuration information only.
 Any reports associated with the project will be lost.
 Upon completion of transfer, this project will not be available in the current account the project is associated with.

text.solarMeteo: Access monthly statistics and hourly profiles of solar irradiance and meteorological data for your project location.
text.pvElectricity: Access monthly statistics and hourly profiles of theoretical electricity production for your plant configuration.
text.pvPerformance: See a detailed breakdown analysis of losses.
text.reports: Generate and download an official Solargis Prospect report for your power plant configuration. Share it with your clients or investors. Our reports are available in multiple languages.
text.download: Download solar and meteorological data of your project for further analysis in 3rd party tools.
text.compareTool: Compare the statistics of multiple sites side-by-side to find an optimum location for your plant.

data.title: Export monthly average data in CSV format for direct import to PVsyst.
data.note: Note: In PVsyst, hourly GHI, DIF, and TEMP data are synthetically generated upon import of monthly average data. The synthetic generation of typical year dataset is a mathematical process that results in loss of the coherence between solar irradiance and air temperature. Also, the frequency distribution of the hourly values in the resulting artificial time series may not represent real conditions of the climate. As the performance of solar power systems varies with solar irradiance and air temperature, use of synthetic hourly dataset increases the uncertainty of solar energy simulations. Therefore it is recommended to use Solargis Time series or TMY datasets for simulation in PVsyst.

daylength.label: Day length and solar zenith angle

IRRProject.name: IRR project
IRRProject.desc: Internal rate of return over the PV system's lifetime of the whole project

IRREquity.name: IRR equity
IRREquity.desc: Internal rate of return over the PV system's lifetime from the shareholder's perspective (excluding loan)

ROIEquity.name: ROI
ROIEquity.desc: Return on investment for the lifetime of a PV system relative to the cost of the investment (CAPEX), where zero (0) marks a break-even (discount rate not used)

LCOE.name: LCOE
LCOE.desc: Cost of a unit of energy over the PV system's lifetime

tariff.desc: Contracted price, at which generated solar electricity is sold to the grid. PPA is usually applied for commercial PV power plants
tariff.name: Power purchase agreement / Feed in tariff

unitSystemCosts.name: Unit system costs
unitSystemCosts.desc: Cost of PV system per kWp (Wp)

incentiveOrRebate.desc: Any monetary or tax incentive offered by the utility company or the government
incentiveOrRebate.name: Installation incentives or rebates

CAPEX.name: CAPEX
CAPEX.desc: Amount of capital needed to install a solar PV system after subtracting solar incentives from the total system cost

loanLinearPayment.desc: Fixed payment amount on a loan
loanLinearPayment.name: Linear loan repayment

maintenanceReserve.desc: Annually contributed sum of money needed for hardware replacements (primarily inverters)
maintenanceReserve.name: Maintenance reserve account
maintenanceReserve.tooltip: Cost of all inverter replacements. Usually, manufacturer’s warranty fluctuates between 5 – 12 years and needs to be replaced on average 2x over the typical length of system operation (25 years)

linearDeprecation.name: Linear tax depreciation
linearDeprecation.desc: Lineary applied reduction in the value of an asset over time, due to aging, degradation and general wear and tear

inverterReplacementYear.name: Year of inverter replacement
inverterReplacementYear.desc: Operational year in which inverter replacement will take place, after which maintenance reserve account (MRA) is dissolved

OPEX.desc: Sum of yearly operational costs of a PV power system, and equated yearly installments for its components replacement
OPEX.name: OPEX

discountRate.name: Discount rate
discountRate.desc: Discounting factor used in Net present value calculations for IRR

tariffGoalseek.explain: The calculation for particular, user-defined IRR Equity output by adjusting the Revenue tariff (PPA/FiT) input, while all other input parameters will remain unchanged.

error.noProject: No project selected. Please select a project to view project detail.

sources.POPUL: Gridded Population of the World, version 4 (GPWv4)
sources.aerosolsMerra: Aerosols from MERRA-2 and MACC-II/CAMS models
sources.region5: Meteosat MFG, MSG (IODC) and Himawari satellites
sources.regionGeneral: Geostationary satellites Meteosat, GOES, MTSAT and HIMAWARI
sources.wapourCSFR: Water vapour from CSFR and GFS models

text.row0: Time step: Monthly and yearly long-term statistics
text.row1: The estimations assume a year having 365 days
text.text: This report is based on high-resolution solar and meteorological database developed and operated by Solargis. The data parameters presented in this report are computed by Solargis models and algorithms. The data used as inputs to the models come from different sources. The data characteristics are explained below.

overview.longtermPvPowerPotential: Long-term PV power potential (average of {years} years)
overview.theoreticalPvElectricityPotential: Theoretical PV electricity potential (at system start-up)
overview.title: Overview - solar radiation and meteorological parameters

pvElectricity.hourlySummary: PV power production profiles, shown below, are calculated as an average of all hourly data for each month. The profiles give an indication of changing power production patterns due to weather and the selected configuration of a PV system in the course of a day. It should be noted that the “average daily profile” is a theoretical concept, as in the majority of cases a profile is specific for each individual day of the year due to weather variability.
pvElectricity.summary: Theoretical estimate of solar electricity production by a photovoltaic system without considering the long-term ageing and performance degradation of PV modules and other system components.

pvLosses.diagramDesc: Diagram shows theoretical losses due to energy conversion in the PV power system
pvLosses.summary: Theoretical yearly specific estimate of solar electricity production by a photovoltaic system without considering the long-term ageing and performance degradation of PV modules and other system components. Long-term average performance ratio (PR) is calculated for a start-up production of a PV system.
pvLosses.title: Energy conversion and related losses

capacityFactor.desc: The ratio of actual electrical energy output over a year to the maximum possible electrical energy output over a given period of time (usually year) expressed in %. The maximum possible power production is the installed AC capacity multiplied by the number of hours in a year, while the actual production is the amount of electricity effectively delivered annually by the PV power plant
capacityFactor.name: Capacity factor

ac_out_with_ac_losses.desc: Theoretical amount of electricity produced by a PV system at the startup of operation. At this stage, degradation of PV modules is not taken into account.
ac_out_with_ac_losses.name: Total system performance (at system startup)

ac_out_with_ac_losses_and_snow_losses_an.desc: The amount of electricity produced by a PV system at the startup of operation with consideration of the unavailability of production due to snow or failures. At this stage, degradation of PV modules is not taken into account.
ac_out_with_ac_losses_and_snow_losses_an.name: Total system performance considering technical availability and losses due to snow

ghi.desc: Theoretical global horizontal irradiation reduced by the portion of irradiation blocked by far horizon and terrain objects.
ghi.name: Global horizontal irradiation site specific

ghi_theoretical.desc: Global horizontal irradiation calculated by Solargis's method from numerical models, which are parameterized by a set of inputs characterizing the cloud transmittance and state of the atmosphere.
ghi_theoretical.name: Global horizontal irradiation (GHI) theoretical

gti.desc: Average annual, monthly or daily sum of global tilted irradiation (often referred to as Plain of array [POA] irradiation)
gti.name: Global tilted irradiation (GTI)

gti_eff.desc: Effective tilted irradiation that reaches the surface of the PV modules with optical losses considered.
gti_eff.name: GTI effective

angularReflectivity.desc: Optical losses from angular reflectivity (angle of incidence effects) on the surface of PV modules where the magnitude of effects depends on the relative position of the sun, plane of the module, and type and cleanliness of the modules surface.
angularReflectivity.name: Angular reflectivity

conversionToSurfaceOfPvModules.desc: Calculation of tilted irradiation (often referred to as plain of array irradiation) from site-specific global horizontal irradiation through direct and diffuse components.
conversionToSurfaceOfPvModules.name: Conversion to surface of PV modules

dirtDustAndSoiling.desc: Optical losses of solar radiation at the level of surface of PV modules due to surface pollution.
dirtDustAndSoiling.name: Dirt, dust and soiling

interRowShading.desc: Losses of electricity due to a decrease in irradiation, which is caused by the preceding rows of PV modules blocking the irradiation.
interRowShading.name: Electrical losses due to inter-row shading

inverters.desc: Losses in inverter due to the efficiency of the conversion process from direct to alternate current. If inverter contains built-in transformer, its efficiency is included in this parameter.
inverters.name: Inverters (DC/AC) conversion

mismatchAndCablingDC.desc: Losses of electricity caused by the mismatch of different MPP operating points of modules connected into an inverter and heat losses in the direct current (DC) interconnections and cables.
mismatchAndCablingDC.name: Mismatch and cabling in DC section

powerTolarance.desc: Losses of electricity due to unequal power tolerance of particular modules connected in string. If modules with higher power tolerance are connected in a series, the losses are higher.
powerTolarance.name: Power tolerance of PV modules

snow.desc: Losses of electricity production during a period of time when PV modules are covered by snow.
snow.name: Losses due to snow

solarIrradianceToDC.desc: Photovoltaic conversion of irradiation into electricity in semiconductor material. The conversion efficiency is non-linear and depends on the distribution of both irradiation and temperature values
solarIrradianceToDC.name: Conversion of solar radiation to DC in the modules

spectralCorrection.desc: Losses in the energy conversion process caused by spectral mismatch between the properties of the semiconductor material and light spectrum
spectralCorrection.name: Spectral correction

technicalAvailablity.desc: Losses of electricity production incurred by the shutdown of a PV power plant due to maintenance, failures or shutdown of the local substation.
technicalAvailablity.name: Technical availability

terrainShading.desc: Loss in theoretical global horizontal irradiation caused by terrain features. Shading is calculated by disaggregation using SRTM-3 DEM and horizon height. Shading from local features such as nearby buildings, structures or vegetation is not relevant at this stage.
terrainShading.name: Horizon shading (terrain + horizon objects)

transformersAndAC.desc: External MV or HV transformer electricity losses and heat losses in alternate current (AC) cabling and connections. This parameter includes losses in AC cables on the low-voltage side, losses in AC cables on the medium (high) voltage side (up to grid connection point with electricity meter), and also on all devices which are in the path of AC current produced by inverters.
transformersAndAC.name: Transformer and AC cabling losses

pvPerformance.lifetimeSummary: Yearly average estimate of solar electricity production by a photovoltaic system. This value considers the PV system configuration and also takes into account the decline of system performance due to ageing and the performance degradation of PV modules and other components. The concept of specific PV power output is useful for comparing different projects or PV system configurations. Performance ratio (PR) shows the average efficiency over the lifetime of a PV system, taking into account the reduction in system performance.

reports.confirmDelete: Are you sure you want to delete this report?
reports.empty: No saved reports. To generate a new report, press Generate button.
reports.title: Generate a report from the current configuration. Reports will be retained until the configuration of the project changes.

shared.noPvConfig: Only solar and meteorological parameters are calculated. No PV configuration is considered.

solarMeteo.hourlySummary: Solar radiation and air temperature profiles, shown below, are calculated as an average of all hourly data for each month. The profiles give an indication of the changing patterns of key meteorological parameters during day. These patterns are determined by the solar astronomy and geography of the project. Global tilted irradiation shows how the optimally-tilted surfaces of photovoltaic modules influence the average availability of the solar resource for power production during an average day. It should be noted that the “average daily profile” is a theoretical concept, as in the majority of cases a profile is specific for each individual day of the year due to weather variability.
solarMeteo.summary: The most important project-specific meteorological parameter that determines solar electricity production is solar radiation, which fuels a PV power system. Power production is also influenced by air temperature. Other meteorological parameters also affect the performance, availability and ageing of a PV system.

sunpath.label: Project horizon and sunpath
sunpath.horizonInvalid: Horizon specified in input is invalid

unsavedProjectDialog.body: To open a Project detail, your currently selected project needs to be saved. Would you like to save this project?
unsavedProjectDialog.heading: Unsaved project

error.missing: You don't have any active PV configuration selected on this project. To access PV data, you need to add one.

pvModule.customDegradation: with {degradationFirstYear}% first year and {degradationNextYear}% next years degradation
pvModule.headline: PV module type

snowSoilingLosses.headline: Snow and soiling losses at PV modules
snowSoilingLosses.soilingAsYearly: I would rather input yearly soiling value

buildingIntegrated.desc: Photovoltaic system integrated into a facade or roof of a residential or commercial building. Azimuth and tilt of PV modules are homogeneous. The modules do not shade each other. The modules are integrated into a building envelope, thus back-side ventilation is very limited. This type of PV system may be directly connected to a low-voltage grid through an inverter, or may be connected to a medium-voltage grid through an inverter and distribution transformer. No electricity storage is considered.
buildingIntegrated.name: Building integrated

groundFixed.desc: Large-scale commercial photovoltaic system mounted on leveled ground. Azimuth and tilt of PV modules are homogeneous, usually facing towards the Equator and inclined at the optimum tilt to maximize yearly energy yield. The modules are fix-mounted on tilted structures aligned in rows. During low-sun angles,  they may be partially shaded by preceding rows. The modules are well ventilated. This type of PV system is connected to a medium- or high-voltage grid through an inverter and distribution transformer, and an additional transformer may also be used. No electricity storage is considered.
groundFixed.name: Ground based fix-mounted

noPvSystem.desc: Only solar and meteorological parameters are calculated. No PV configuration is considered.
noPvSystem.name: No PV system

rooftopLargeFlat.desc: Photovoltaic system mounted on a large horizontal roof of a commercial or industrial building. Azimuth and tilt of the PV modules are homogeneous. The modules are fix-mounted on tilted structures, attached to the flat roof and aligned in rows. Thus, during low sun angles, the modules may be partially shaded by preceding rows. The mounting enables the ventilation of PV modules, but heating from the roof surface may affect the performance of the PV system. This type of PV system may be directly connected to a low-voltage grid through an inverter, or it may be connected to a medium-voltage grid through an inverter and distribution transformer. No electricity storage is considered.
rooftopLargeFlat.name: Rooftop large flat roof

rooftopLargeTilted.desc: Photovoltaic system mounted on a large tilted roof of a commercial or industrial building. Azimuth and tilt of PV modules are homogeneous and the modules do not shade each other. The modules are mounted on rails attached to a tilted roof, thus back-side ventilation is possible. This system may be directly connected to a low-voltage grid through an inverter, or may be connected to a medium-voltage grid through an inverter and distribution transformer. No electricity storage is considered.
rooftopLargeTilted.name: Rooftop large tilted roof

rooftopSmall.desc: Photovoltaic system mounted on a tilted roof of a residential building. Azimuth and tilt of the PV modules are homogeneous and the modules do not shade each other. The modules are mounted on rails attached to a tilted roof, thus allowing back-side ventilation. This type of PV system is usually directly connected to a low-voltage grid through an inverter. No electricity storage is considered.
rooftopSmall.name: Rooftop small

trackerOneAxisHorizontalNS.desc: Large-scale commercial photovoltaic system mounted on leveled ground. PV modules are mounted on trackers with one horizontal axis North-South bound. Rotation limits for tracker are given for both East and West directions. Backtracking algorithm is used for reduction of shading loses between rows during low sun angles. The modules are well ventilated. This type of PV system is connected to a medium- or high-voltage grid through an inverter and distribution transformer, and an additional transformer may also be used. No electricity storage is considered.
trackerOneAxisHorizontalNS.name: Tracker with 1 horizontal axis

hydroMountedLargeScale.name: Floating PV
hydroMountedLargeScale.desc: This option covers large floating solar PV installations. It is considered that modules are assembled on plastic floating pontoons, oriented towards the equator. Modules have lower operational temperature due to cooling by evaporation of surface water. A higher mismatch between modules in a string (wave-induced mismatch) and higher soiling due to bird droppings is expected. In this example installation, string inverters and distribution transformer are considered. In comparison to large-scale ground-mounted PV installations, the expected availability of the system is lower due to a harsher environment, with a higher probability of occurrence of various failure types.

legal.guarantee: Considering the uncertainty of data and calculations, Solargis s.r.o. does not guarantee the accuracy of estimates. The maximum possible has been done for the assessment of weather parameters and preliminary assessment of the photovoltaic electricity production based on the best available data, software and knowledge. Solargis s.r.o. shall not be liable for any direct, incidental, consequential, indirect or punitive damages arising or alleged to have arisen out of use of the provided report.
legal.moreInfo: More information about full PV yield assessment can be found at:
legal.terms: See full text of GENERAL CONTRACTUAL TERMS TO THE PAID SERVICES at:
legal.title: Disclaimer and legal information
legal.trademark: Solargis® is a trade mark of Solargis s.r.o.
legal.uncertainty: This report shows solar power estimation in the start-up phase and over the entire lifetime of a PV system. The estimates are accurate enough for preliminary project assessment. For large projects planning and financing, more information is needed: 1. Statistical distribution and uncertainty of solar radiation 2. Detailed specification of a PV system 3. Inter-annual variability and P90 uncertainty of PV production 4. Lifetime energy production considering performance degradation of PV components.
legal.validationAuthText: This PDF report is electronically signed by Solargis s.r.o..

report.solarDailySummary: Solar radiation profiles below are calculated as an average of all hourly data for each month. The profiles give an indication of changing patterns of GHI per day, separately for each month. These patterns are driven by local geography, astronomy and climate of the site.
